text:
SPEAKER 1: We had
Ebola, all right?

Now, we are facing the
challenges of COVID.

It's interesting to
me how technology

is playing such a role in both
the solution to the problems,

but also in how
we've adjusted to it.

Could you comment on
those kinds of issues,

especially as they
confront Africa?

SPEAKER 2: We were
sort of prepared
for COVID because of Ebola.

And that's because the way
that we manage Ebola was very--

to use your words--
was very data-driven.

It was very data
driven in the sense

that even during
the Ebola crisis,

there was a lot of
the track and trace

that Lagos state was using
even though many people didn't
realize.

It was really around
collecting data,

a lot of data around
where people were,

where the disease was and
what the impact and all that.

So that experience really in
a sense prepared us for COVID.

But not well enough,
to be honest,

because I think that if
COVID was as deadly as it

was in other parts of the
world, we really wouldn't have--
really wouldn't have survived.

But I think that
what is happening now

with technology
and health, I think

it's addresses some of
the major challenges

that we're faced with
as a country when
it comes to health.

There are challenges
around fake drugs.

There are challenges
around drug distribution.

There are challenges around
the doctor to patient ratio.

There are challenges
around the cost of health.

And so most people are having to
pay for their health needs out
of their pocket.
There's no health insurance.

And we're seeing the way
the technology is solving

many of these problems we're
seeing the way that we're

using RFID to test
whether a drug in a box
is a fake one or real one.

We're using technology to really
be able to distribute drugs
to where it's needed.
So using-- how do I put it now--

mobile ordering systems,
inventory management systems

to ensure that pharmacies
are well stocked

and you're getting the drugs
to them at the right time.

Telemedicine is becoming because
of COVID and the distance
and everything.

For other parts of the world,
what it helped us solve

was the fact that I don't
want to go to a hospital

because I don't
want to catch COVID.

But in this part of the
world, what is solvent

is that, we don't
have enough doctors.

And so people have to
travel miles to see doctors.

And so now we have all
these telemedicine companies

where you can actually
see a doctor on a screen

because apparently
80% of diagnosis

can be done without having to
actually physically examine
the patient.

So we're seeing
technology really

help us-- it's accelerated
because of COVID.

But I think that the
problems of access,

the problems of quality,
the problems of drugs,

we're really using technology
to solve those problems.

And I honestly
believe that health

is one area where
technology is going

to play a major role to help
us solve some of the really

big challenges that we have in
this country where people are

dying needlessly because
they've either taken a fake drug

or they haven't seen a
doctor quickly enough
or they got the wrong diagnosis.
